questions.question: Who is considered the father of modern computing?
questions.explanation: Alan Turing is widely considered the father of modern computing for his work on the Turing machine and his contributions to breaking the Enigma code during World War II.

questions.question: What was ENIAC?
options: One of the first electronic general-purpose computers
questions.explanation: ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer) was one of the first electronic general-purpose computers, completed in 1945. It weighed 30 tons and occupied 1,800 square feet.

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 while working at CERN. He created the first web browser, web server, and HTTP protocol.

questions.question: In what year was the first iPhone released?
questions.explanation: The first iPhone was released by Apple on June 29, 2007. It revolutionized the smartphone industry with its touchscreen interface and mobile computing capabilities.

questions.question: Which company developed the first commercially successful personal computer?
questions.explanation: Apple's Apple II, released in 1977, was one of the first highly successful mass-produced personal computers, featuring color graphics and an open architecture.

questions.question: What was the first computer bug?
options: An actual moth trapped in a computer relay
questions.explanation: The term 'bug' was popularized in 1947 when an actual moth was found trapped in a relay of the Harvard Mark II computer. The moth was taped into the logbook with the note 'First actual case of bug being found.'

questions.question: Who co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates?
questions.explanation: Paul Allen co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates in 1975. Together they developed software for early personal computers and built Microsoft into a technology giant.

questions.question: What was the name of the first web browser?
questions.explanation: The first web browser was called 'WorldWideWeb' (later renamed 'Nexus'), created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1990. It was both a browser and an editor.

questions.question: What does 'Moore's Law' predict?
options: The number of transistors on a chip doubles approximately every two years
questions.explanation: Moore's Law, proposed by Gordon Moore in 1965, predicts that the number of transistors on integrated circuits doubles approximately every two years, leading to exponential growth in computing power.

questions.question: When was the first email sent?
questions.explanation: The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971. He also introduced the '@' symbol to separate the user name from the computer name in email addresses.
